items.title: News Wrap: Trump orders Pentagon to use ‘all available funds’ to pay troops amid shutdown
items.standfirst: In our news wrap Saturday, Trump directed the Defense Department to ensure U.S. troops are paid on time as the government shutdown continues, authorities said there are no survivors from Friday’s blast that leveled a Tennessee explosives plant, and actor and producer Diane Keaton died at age 79.
items.content: In our news wrap Saturday, Trump directed the Defense Department to ensure U.S. troops are paid on time as the government shutdown continues, authorities said there are no survivors from Friday’s blast that leveled a Tennessee explosives plant, and actor and producer Diane Keaton died at age 79.

items.title: Trump says military members will be paid despite government shutdown
items.standfirst: President claims he found a way to pay troops and directed Pentagon chief to release funds on 15 OctoberDonald Trump claimed on Saturday that he has found a way to pay US military troops despite the ongoing federal government shutdown, saying he has instructed his defence secretary, Pete Hegseth, to release funds.Posting on his Truth Social platform, Trump wrote: “I am using my authority, as commander-in-chief, to direct our secretary of war, Pete Hegseth, to use all available funds to get our troops PAID on October 15.” Continue reading...
items.content: President claims he found a way to pay troops and directed Pentagon chief to release funds on 15 OctoberDonald Trump claimed on Saturday that he has found a way to pay US military troops despite the ongoing federal government shutdown, saying he has instructed his defence secretary, Pete Hegseth, to release funds.Posting on his Truth Social platform, Trump wrote: “I am using my authority, as commander-in-chief, to direct our secretary of war, Pete Hegseth, to use all available funds to get our troops PAID on October 15.” Continue reading...

items.title: Sheriff says Tennessee explosives factory blast left no survivors
items.standfirst: A blast on Friday at the rural Tennessee Accurate Energetic Systems plant, which supplies and researches explosives for the military left no survivors, authorities said, adding that the 18 people inside the building are presumed to be deceased. State officials brought in a “rapid DNA” team to help identify the remains and said it could be days, weeks or even months before foul play is ruled out.
items.content: A blast on Friday at the rural Tennessee Accurate Energetic Systems plant, which supplies and researches explosives for the military left no survivors, authorities said, adding that the 18 people inside the building are presumed to be deceased. State officials brought in a “rapid DNA” team to help identify the remains and said it could be days, weeks or even months before foul play is ruled out.

items.title: No survivors from blast at Tennessee explosives factory, sheriff says
items.standfirst: The blast in rural Tennessee that leveled an explosives plant and was felt for miles around left no survivors, authorities said Saturday. The total number of dead was unclear, as was the cause of the Friday blast.
items.content: The blast in rural Tennessee that leveled an explosives plant and was felt for miles around left no survivors, authorities said Saturday. The total number of dead was unclear, as was the cause of the Friday blast.

items.title: No survivors in Tennessee explosives factory blast, officials say
items.standfirst: Initial toll after explosions at plant near McEwen on Friday was believed to be 19 people but later revised to 18.There were no survivors in the blast that obliterated part of an explosives factory in rural Tennessee, authorities said on Saturday.The families of 18 people had been waiting anxiously on Saturday as their loved ones had been feared dead since explosions ripped through the plant near McEwen in western Tennessee early on Friday. The initial toll had been believed to be 19 people but that figure was later revised. Continue reading...
items.content: Initial toll after explosions at plant near McEwen on Friday was believed to be 19 people but later revised to 18.There were no survivors in the blast that obliterated part of an explosives factory in rural Tennessee, authorities said on Saturday.The families of 18 people had been waiting anxiously on Saturday as their loved ones had been feared dead since explosions ripped through the plant near McEwen in western Tennessee early on Friday. The initial toll had been believed to be 19 people but that figure was later revised. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump lays off thousands of US government workers amid govt shutdown
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Friday blamed Democrats for his decision to lay off thousands of workers across the US government as he followed through on his threat to cut the federal workforce during the government shutdown.
items.content: President Donald Trump on Friday blamed Democrats for his decision to lay off thousands of workers across the US government as he followed through on his threat to cut the federal workforce during the government shutdown.

items.title: Blast at Tennessee explosives plant leaves dozens missing and feared dead
items.standfirst: A blast leveled an explosives plant Friday in rural Tennessee, leaving behind a mass of twisted metal, burned-out shells of cars and at least 18 people missing and feared dead, authorities said. “There’s nothing to describe. It’s gone,” Humphreys County Sheriff Chris Davis said of the blast site at Accurate Energetic Systems, which supplies and researches explosives for the military.
items.content: A blast leveled an explosives plant Friday in rural Tennessee, leaving behind a mass of twisted metal, burned-out shells of cars and at least 18 people missing and feared dead, authorities said. “There’s nothing to describe. It’s gone,” Humphreys County Sheriff Chris Davis said of the blast site at Accurate Energetic Systems, which supplies and researches explosives for the military.

ai_summary: Trump directed the Pentagon to ensure military personnel receive timely paychecks.
The government shutdown has lasted eleven days, with a Senate vote pending.
An explosives factory blast in Tennessee had no survivors, authorities confirmed.
The initial missing person count of eighteen was revised to sixteen.
The President announced the military would be paid during the shutdown.

items.content: Thousands of Palestinians began returning to their homes across Gaza on Saturday amid a U.S.-brokered ceasefire.

items.title: More than 500,000 Palestinians return to ruined Gaza City as truce holds
items.standfirst: More than half a million displaced Palestinians have returned to Gaza City since a ceasefire came into effect Friday, Gaza's civil defence agency said on Saturday. Many displaced Palestinians returning home were left stunned by the destruction while others were amazed to find their homes still standing.
items.content: More than half a million displaced Palestinians have returned to Gaza City since a ceasefire came into effect Friday, Gaza's civil defence agency said on Saturday. Many displaced Palestinians returning home were left stunned by the destruction while others were amazed to find their homes still standing.

items.title: Thousands gather in London in march for ‘lasting peace’ in Gaza
items.standfirst: Director of Palestine Solidarity Campaign says ceasefire agreement says nothing about ‘system of apartheid’ in Palestine• Gaza ceasefire – live updatesThousands of people have gathered in central London to call for “lasting peace” in Gaza, a day after the ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas came into effect.The demonstration, organised by the Palestine Solidarity Campaign, began at Victoria Embankment and headed to Whitehall. Stalls sold keffiyehs and people handed out placards that read “from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free”, “it’s not a crime to act against genocide” and “Starmer has blood on his hands, free Palestine”. Continue reading...
items.content: Director of Palestine Solidarity Campaign says ceasefire agreement says nothing about ‘system of apartheid’ in Palestine• Gaza ceasefire – live updatesThousands of people have gathered in central London to call for “lasting peace” in Gaza, a day after the ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas came into effect.The demonstration, organised by the Palestine Solidarity Campaign, began at Victoria Embankment and headed to Whitehall. Stalls sold keffiyehs and people handed out placards that read “from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free”, “it’s not a crime to act against genocide” and “Starmer has blood on his hands, free Palestine”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump prepares Middle East trip after Gaza peace plan agreement
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump wlill travel to the Middle East on Sunday to mark the first phase of his Gaza peace plan. Israel said a ceasefire took effect Friday and its military has begun to withdraw forces from parts of Gaza. As part of the plan, Hamas will release all remaining hostages that were captured during the Oct. 7, 2023 attack. Palestinian residents began returning home Friday.
items.content: President Donald Trump wlill travel to the Middle East on Sunday to mark the first phase of his Gaza peace plan. Israel said a ceasefire took effect Friday and its military has begun to withdraw forces from parts of Gaza. As part of the plan, Hamas will release all remaining hostages that were captured during the Oct. 7, 2023 attack. Palestinian residents began returning home Friday.

items.title: Families of hostages in Gaza await their release
items.standfirst: The families of hostages taken by Hamas on Oct. 7, 2023 are eagerly awaiting the return of their loved ones. The peace deal between Israel and Hamas would see the hostages returned within 72 hours of its implementation Friday.
items.content: The families of hostages taken by Hamas on Oct. 7, 2023 are eagerly awaiting the return of their loved ones. The peace deal between Israel and Hamas would see the hostages returned within 72 hours of its implementation Friday.

items.standfirst: Israeli troops have pulled back from parts of Gaza after Israel approved Donald Trump's ceasefire and hostage release plan.
items.content: Israeli troops have pulled back from parts of Gaza after Israel approved Donald Trump's ceasefire and hostage release plan.

items.title: Thousands of Gazans return home as ceasefire takes effect
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of Palestinians headed back to the heavily destroyed northern Gaza Strip on Friday as a U.S.-brokered ceasefire came into effect in a deal that raised hopes for ending the Israel-Hamas war. All the remaining hostages were set to be released within days.
items.content: Tens of thousands of Palestinians headed back to the heavily destroyed northern Gaza Strip on Friday as a U.S.-brokered ceasefire came into effect in a deal that raised hopes for ending the Israel-Hamas war. All the remaining hostages were set to be released within days.

items.title: Palestinians return as Israeli troops pull back
items.standfirst: Thousands of Palestinians returned home after Israeli troops pulled back, as part of President Trump’s peace deal. Hamas is required to release its hostages by Monday. NBC News’ Richard Engel reports.
items.content: Thousands of Palestinians returned home after Israeli troops pulled back, as part of President Trump’s peace deal. Hamas is required to release its hostages by Monday. NBC News’ Richard Engel reports.

items.title: ‘It’s complete devastation’: Gazans return home to ruins
items.standfirst: Displaced civilians returned to a landscape of rubble and ruins in Khan Younis as the Gaza ceasefire came into effect. “No signs of life are left,” said one man. “Everything has been wiped out.”
items.content: Displaced civilians returned to a landscape of rubble and ruins in Khan Younis as the Gaza ceasefire came into effect. “No signs of life are left,” said one man. “Everything has been wiped out.”

items.title: Palestinians displaced to southern Gaza begin journey home as ceasefire comes into effect
items.standfirst: Thousands walk north along coastal road after Israel-Hamas agreement puts stop to fighting for first time in six monthsTens of thousands of displaced Palestinians in Gaza have begun to return to the ruins of their homes after the ceasefire rapidly negotiated in recent days between Hamas and Israel came into effect at noon local time on Friday – the first relief from relentless violence that inhabitants of the devastated territory have had since March.Israeli troops withdrew to new agreed-upon positions during Friday morning and Hamas is expected to release the 20 living Israeli hostages it is holding early next week, after which Israel will free 250 Palestinians serving long-term sentences in Israeli prisons, as well as 1,700 others detained during the war. Continue reading...
items.content: Thousands walk north along coastal road after Israel-Hamas agreement puts stop to fighting for first time in six monthsTens of thousands of displaced Palestinians in Gaza have begun to return to the ruins of their homes after the ceasefire rapidly negotiated in recent days between Hamas and Israel came into effect at noon local time on Friday – the first relief from relentless violence that inhabitants of the devastated territory have had since March.Israeli troops withdrew to new agreed-upon positions during Friday morning and Hamas is expected to release the 20 living Israeli hostages it is holding early next week, after which Israel will free 250 Palestinians serving long-term sentences in Israeli prisons, as well as 1,700 others detained during the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin Stands up for Trump's Nobel Peace Prize Bid: 'Credibility Has Largely Been Lost'

This follows the Nobel committee’s decision to award the peace prize to María Corina Machado, a Venezuelan opposition leader. Putin voiced his disappointment with the Nobel…

This follows the Nobel committee’s decision to award the peace prize to María Corina Machado, a Venezuelan opposition leader. Putin voiced his disappointment with the Nobel…

items.title: María Corina Machado, Nobel Prize winner, on the fight for democracy in Venezuela
items.standfirst: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for keeping "the flame of democracy burning amid growing darkness." Machado opened up to CBS News about her decades of fighting for fair elections in an exclusive interview while in hiding.
items.content: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for keeping "the flame of democracy burning amid growing darkness." Machado opened up to CBS News about her decades of fighting for fair elections in an exclusive interview while in hiding.

items.title: Maria Corina Machado says her Nobel tells Venezuelans that "we are not alone"
items.standfirst: Maria Corina Machado is the leader of the pro-democracy movement in Venezuela, which is under a dictatorship so brutal she has been forced to live in hiding.
items.content: Maria Corina Machado is the leader of the pro-democracy movement in Venezuela, which is under a dictatorship so brutal she has been forced to live in hiding.

items.title: For Trump world, the focus shifts to next year's Nobel Peace Prize

items.content: The push to make President Donald Trump the winner of the 2026 Nobel Peace Prize began within hours of Venezuela's Maria Corina Machado winning.

items.title: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado wins Nobel Peace Prize

items.title: Venezuelan politician María Corina Machado wins Nobel peace prize
items.standfirst: Opponent of Maduro regime receives award and praise for keeping ‘flame of democracy burning’The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado has won the Nobel peace prize for her dogged struggle to rescue the South American country from its fate as “a brutal, authoritarian state”.Machado, 58, a conservative often described as Venezuela’s Iron Lady, has spent the last year living in hiding after her political movement was widely believed to have beaten the country’s president, Nicolás Maduro, in the July 2024 presidential election. Continue reading...
items.content: Opponent of Maduro regime receives award and praise for keeping ‘flame of democracy burning’The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado has won the Nobel peace prize for her dogged struggle to rescue the South American country from its fate as “a brutal, authoritarian state”.Machado, 58, a conservative often described as Venezuela’s Iron Lady, has spent the last year living in hiding after her political movement was widely believed to have beaten the country’s president, Nicolás Maduro, in the July 2024 presidential election. Continue reading...

items.content: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded Friday to Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado, who lives in hiding after attempting to run for the presidency last year against President Nicolás Maduro

clusters.title: Drone strike in besieged Sudan city kills dozens

The resistance committee for El Fasher said the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary group hit the Dar al-Arqam displacement centre, which is in the grounds of a university

items.title: Sudanese paramilitary attack kills at least 53 people in North Darfur, aid group says
items.standfirst: A shelling and drone attack by the Sudanese paramilitary forces hit a shelter in a besieged city in the Darfur region, killing at least 53 people, a doctors’ group said Saturday. The onslaught was the latest in Sudan's more than two-year war.
items.content: A shelling and drone attack by the Sudanese paramilitary forces hit a shelter in a besieged city in the Darfur region, killing at least 53 people, a doctors’ group said Saturday. The onslaught was the latest in Sudan's more than two-year war.

items.standfirst: At least 53 people, including 14 children and 15 women, have been killed in an attack on a displacement shelter in a besieged city in North Darfur.
items.content: At least 53 people, including 14 children and 15 women, have been killed in an attack on a displacement shelter in a besieged city in North Darfur.

items.standfirst: Four people were killed in an attack in Leland, while two were killed in Heidelberg, amid a third attack in Rolling ForkSix people were killed and 18 others injured in three separate shootings at high school football homecoming celebrations in Mississippi, according to a number of local officials on Saturday.The most fatal incident took place around midnight on Friday in Leland, where four people died, John Lee, the mayor of the small city in Washington county, western Mississippi, said on Saturday morning. clusters.title: Luigi Mangione’s lawyers seek dismissal of federal charges in UnitedHealthcare CEO killing
clusters.neutral_headline: Lawyers seek dismissal of charges in CEO killing
bullet_summary: Reported by Reuters Top News, NPR News

items.title: Luigi Mangione’s lawyers seek dismissal of federal charges in UnitedHealthcare CEO killing
items.standfirst: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione asked a New York federal judge Saturday to dismiss some criminal charges, including the only count for which he could face the death penalty, from a federal indictment brought against him in the December assassination of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive.
items.content: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione asked a New York federal judge Saturday to dismiss some criminal charges, including the only count for which he could face the death penalty, from a federal indictment brought against him in the December assassination of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive.

items.title: Luigi Mangione's lawyers seek a dismissal of federal charges in CEO killing
items.standfirst: Mangione's lawyers asked a federal judge to dismiss some criminal charges, including the only count for which he could face the death penalty, from a federal indictment brought against him.
items.content: Mangione's lawyers asked a federal judge to dismiss some criminal charges, including the only count for which he could face the death penalty, from a federal indictment brought against him.(Image credit: Seth Wenig)

ai_summary: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione seek dismissal of federal charges.
The charges are related to the killing of a UnitedHealthcare CEO.
They are seeking to dismiss the count that could carry the death penalty.
The federal indictment was brought against Mangione in December.
The lawyers filed the request with a New York federal judge.

clusters.title: SNP members back Swinney's independence plan for Holyrood election
clusters.neutral_headline: SNP members back Swinney's independence plan
bullet_summary: Reported by BBC Top Stories, Guardian World

items.title: SNP members back Swinney's independence plan for Holyrood election
items.standfirst: The first minister will declare a mandate for a second independence referendum, if the SNP wins a majority of seats in the 2026 Holyrood election.
items.content: The first minister will declare a mandate for a second independence referendum, if the SNP wins a majority of seats in the 2026 Holyrood election.

items.title: SNP backs Swinney’s ‘clear’ strategy for new independence referendum
items.standfirst: Members overwhelmingly endorse leadership motion that majority at next Holyrood election is only route to second voteSNP members have overwhelmingly backed leader John Swinney’s “clear and unambiguous” independence strategy that a majority election win is the only route to another referendum.On the first day of the party’s annual conference in Aberdeen, the vast majority of members backed the leadership’s motion that next May’s Holyrood elections should be fought on a “clear platform of national independence” and that winning a majority in the Scottish parliament – by securing 65 seats or more – would be “the only uncontested way to deliver a new vote on Scotland’s future”. Continue reading...
items.content: Members overwhelmingly endorse leadership motion that majority at next Holyrood election is only route to second voteSNP members have overwhelmingly backed leader John Swinney’s “clear and unambiguous” independence strategy that a majority election win is the only route to another referendum.On the first day of the party’s annual conference in Aberdeen, the vast majority of members backed the leadership’s motion that next May’s Holyrood elections should be fought on a “clear platform of national independence” and that winning a majority in the Scottish parliament – by securing 65 seats or more – would be “the only uncontested way to deliver a new vote on Scotland’s future”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: SNP members support Swinney's independence strategy.
The strategy involves a second independence referendum.
A majority of seats in the 2026 election is the only route.
The SNP must win a majority in the Holyrood election.
The party held its annual conference in Aberdeen.

clusters.title: Déjà vu as French President reappoints Sébastien LeCornu Prime Minister
clusters.neutral_headline: France's Prime Minister reappointed after resignation
bullet_summary: France's reappointed Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu said Saturday he was to form a government "not imprisoned by the parties" to tackle a political crisis "painful for everyone"
Lecornu, who was reinstated just days after resigning, now faces a race against the clock to deliver a 2026 budget bill by Monday and attempt to sway a fractious parliament
Sébastien Lecornu resigned on Monday after 26 days in the job and he said two days later his "mission is over"

items.title: Déjà vu as French President reappoints Sébastien LeCornu Prime Minister
items.standfirst: It's been quite a week in French Politics. Sébastien LeCornu stepped down from his post as Prime Minister on Monday, on Friday President Emmanuel Macron reappointed him. In between, there have been meetings with the various political parties. The National Assembly remains in gridlock and time to pass a budget before the end of the year is running out.
items.content: It's been quite a week in French Politics. Sébastien LeCornu stepped down from his post as Prime Minister on Monday, on Friday President Emmanuel Macron reappointed him. In between, there have been meetings with the various political parties. The National Assembly remains in gridlock and time to pass a budget before the end of the year is running out.

items.title: Returning PM Lecornu says wants govt free from party jockeying
items.standfirst: France's reappointed Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu said Saturday he was to form a government "not imprisoned by the parties" to tackle a political crisis "painful for everyone". Speaking publicly for the first time since his reappointement, Lecornu unscored the importance of putting together a cabinet with members that do not have political ambitions for the 2027 presidential elections, FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot said, reporting from Paris.
items.content: France's reappointed Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu said Saturday he was to form a government "not imprisoned by the parties" to tackle a political crisis "painful for everyone". Speaking publicly for the first time since his reappointement, Lecornu unscored the importance of putting together a cabinet with members that do not have political ambitions for the 2027 presidential elections, FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot said, reporting from Paris.

items.title: ‘Worst job in France’: Sébastien Lecornu reprises role as prime minister
items.standfirst: Outgoing Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu is back in his role after French President Emmanuel Macron reappointed him on Friday. Described by some as having the “worst job in France,” Lecornu once again faces the tough task of forming a government amid political deadlock. FRANCE 24 speaks to Paul Smith, head of modern languages at the Unversity of Nottingham to shed more light on the situation.
items.content: Outgoing Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu is back in his role after French President Emmanuel Macron reappointed him on Friday. Described by some as having the “worst job in France,” Lecornu once again faces the tough task of forming a government amid political deadlock. FRANCE 24 speaks to Paul Smith, head of modern languages at the Unversity of Nottingham to shed more light on the situation.

items.title: Reappointed French PM Lecornu says new cabinet 'must not be hostage to partisan interests'
items.standfirst: France's reappointed Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu warned on Saturday that his next cabinet must not be "held hostage" by political parties as he vowed to tackle a deepening political crisis. Lecornu, who was reinstated just days after resigning, now faces a race against the clock to deliver a 2026 budget bill by Monday and attempt to sway a fractious parliament.
items.content: France's reappointed Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu warned on Saturday that his next cabinet must not be "held hostage" by political parties as he vowed to tackle a deepening political crisis. Lecornu, who was reinstated just days after resigning, now faces a race against the clock to deliver a 2026 budget bill by Monday and attempt to sway a fractious parliament.

items.title: 'The clock is ticking': Lecornu faces tight deadline to form government
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu, recently reappointed as prime minister, is scrambling to assemble a new cabinet amid deep political uncertainty. FRANCE 24’s Olivia Bizot says “the clock is ticking,” noting that Lecornu has only until Sunday evening to form a government and present a budget by Monday.
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu, recently reappointed as prime minister, is scrambling to assemble a new cabinet amid deep political uncertainty. FRANCE 24’s Olivia Bizot says “the clock is ticking,” noting that Lecornu has only until Sunday evening to form a government and present a budget by Monday.

items.title: President Macron reappoints Lecornu as French PM
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron reappointed Sebastien Lecornu as prime minister on Friday just days after he quit the job, a move that enraged some of the president's fiercest political opponents who pledged to vote out the new government.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron reappointed Sebastien Lecornu as prime minister on Friday just days after he quit the job, a move that enraged some of the president's fiercest political opponents who pledged to vote out the new government.

items.title: Macron reappoints Lecornu as French PM after days of turmoil
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu resigned on Monday after 26 days in the job and he said two days later his "mission is over".
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu resigned on Monday after 26 days in the job and he said two days later his "mission is over".

ai_summary: Sébastien LeCornu was reappointed as Prime Minister.
He resigned from the position earlier in the week.
He is tasked with forming a government amid political gridlock.
He wants a cabinet free from party jockeying.
He faces a deadline to deliver a 2026 budget bill.

clusters.title: Pakistani Taliban attacks on security forces kill more than 20 in restive northwest
clusters.neutral_headline: Pakistani Taliban attacks kill security forces
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, BBC World

items.title: Pakistani Taliban attacks on security forces kill more than 20 in restive northwest
items.standfirst: Pakistani Taliban militants have claimed responsibility for separate attacks that killed 20 security officers and three civilians in the northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province that borders Afghanistan. Friday's attacks came hours after the Afghan Taliban government accused Pakistan of "violating Kabul's sovereign territory".
items.content: Pakistani Taliban militants have claimed responsibility for separate attacks that killed 20 security officers and three civilians in the northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province that borders Afghanistan. Friday's attacks came hours after the Afghan Taliban government accused Pakistan of "violating Kabul's sovereign territory".

items.title: Afghanistan accuses Pakistan of 'violating sovereign territory'
items.standfirst: The allegation by the Taliban came after two loud blasts were heard in the city late on Thursday.
items.content: The allegation by the Taliban came after two loud blasts were heard in the city late on Thursday.

ai_summary: Pakistani Taliban attacks killed over twenty security officers.
The attacks occurred in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
Three civilians were also killed in the attacks.
The attacks happened near the border with Afghanistan.
The Afghan Taliban accused Pakistan of violating territory.

clusters.title: Hamas official thanks Donald Trump for ceasefire deal - but tells Sky News Tony Blair not welcome
clusters.neutral_headline: Hamas official thanks Trump for ceasefire deal
bullet_summary: Reported by Sky News World, NBC World

items.title: Hamas official thanks Donald Trump for ceasefire deal - but tells Sky News Tony Blair not welcome
items.standfirst: A senior Hamas official has thanked President Donald Trump for his role in securing a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas.
items.content: A senior Hamas official has thanked President Donald Trump for his role in securing a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas.

items.title: How the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal came together
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump had to maintain the trust of Israel and a series of Arab- and Muslim-majority nations. His ability to walk that tightrope was tested repeatedly.
items.content: President Donald Trump had to maintain the trust of Israel and a series of Arab- and Muslim-majority nations. His ability to walk that tightrope was tested repeatedly.

ai_summary: A Hamas official thanked Donald Trump for the ceasefire.
The official acknowledged Trump's role in the deal.
The official said Tony Blair was not welcome.
The ceasefire was between Israel and Hamas.
The deal involved multiple Arab and Muslim nations.
